description: From Middle English jugge, iugge, of uncertain origin. Possibly a variant of Middle English jubbe, jobbe, iubbe, geobbe, itself of unknown origin; or perhaps continuing (in altered form) Old English ċēac (“pitcher; jug”). Compare also jug (“a low woman, maidservant”), from Jug, familiar form of Joanna.

entries.meaning: A serving vessel or container, typically circular in cross-section and typically higher than it is wide, with a relatively small mouth or spout, an ear handle and often a stopper or top.
The amount that a jug can hold.

examples: I was 'counsel for the defence', or 'prisoner's friend'. My chap had deserted for nearly two years and spent six months in a civvy jug. With papers under my arm and serious countenance I visited him in his cell day after day,  […]

entries.meaning: (vulgar, slang, chiefly in the plural) A woman's breasts.
(CB radio slang, chiefly in the plural) A kind of large, high-powered vacuum tube.
examples: […]  as shown in the August 2000 issue, using a pair of my favorite jugs, 807s.

entries.meaning: (climbing) A hold large enough for both hands

verbs.description: jug (third-person singular simple present jugs, present participle jugging, simple past and past participle jugged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To stew in an earthenware jug etc.
(intransitive) To utter a sound like "jug", as certain birds do, especially the nightingale.
(intransitive, of quails or partridges) To nestle or collect together in a covey.
A small mixed breed of dog created by mating a Jack Russell terrier and a pug.
examples: When the dog’s owners returned with their shopping, I asked what the little dog was. She was a Jug, a Jack Russell-Pug cross. We found out lots about this crossbreed, thought long and hard, and decided a Jug and a Spitz could work really well together.

description: Probably from Latin jugum. A folk etymology claims that it is an acronym for "justice under God" or "judgment under God". [1][2]

entries.meaning: (US, Roman Catholicism, countable or uncountable) detention (after-school student punishment)

verbs.description: jug (third-person singular simple present jugs, present participle jugging, simple past and past participle jugged)

entries.meaning: (US, Roman Catholicism, transitive) to issue a detention (to a student)
